Go Weekly

A Taste of Go Code Generator Magic: A Quick Guide to GettingÂ Started â€” There arenâ€™t many tutorials on Go code generation, which inspired the author to show how they created a program to generate boilerplate to wrap functions. You, too, could generate some code and freeÂ time.

Valentin Kiselev (Evil Martians)

Leveraging benchstat Projections in Go Benchmark Analysis â€” benchstat is a stdlib tool that compares and contrasts benchmark data generated by Go benchmark tests. This post brings you up to speed with what benchstat offers and why you might want to useÂ it.

Bartek PÅ‚otka

Go Beyond Limits with Golang, Rust, Docker &Â K8s â€” Struggling with tech challenges? Ardan Labs offers unparalleled consulting in Go, Rust, Docker, and Kubernetes. Enhance your development speed, optimize your architecture, and manage tech debt. Propel your team to new heights with ourÂ expertise!

Ardan Labs Consulting sponsor

Speeding Up Calculations 450% with Go Assembly â€” Goâ€™s assembler is heavily inspired by Plan 9â€™s (with Rob Pike and Ken Thompson, along with others, creating both). The author investigates using Goâ€™s assembler to implement a particularly speedy SIMD (Same Instruction Multiple Data) library for Go. Thereâ€™s also an interesting thread on Hacker News where Russ Cox (as rsc) adds someÂ context.

Jacob Ray Pehringer

Optimizing and Visualizing Test Parallelism: Why More Cores Don't Speed Up Your Go Tests â€” Youâ€™re probably aware of t.Parallel() to run tests in parallel, but did you know it can sometimes slow tests down? Robert runs through some tools and tactics to help visualize and optimize tests and when to bother running them inÂ parallel.

Robert Laszczak

ğŸ“„ How I Wrote Express-Go in 19 Hours â€“ GopherLight is an Express.js inspired framework, but forÂ Go. Bruno Ciccarino

ğŸ“„ How to Deploy a Gin App on Railway â€“ A new guide for the Railway app deploymentÂ platform. Railway

Excelize 2.9: A Pure Go Way to Work with Excel Spreadsheets â€” Read and write XLAM / XLSM / XLSX / XLTM and XLTX files. A long time library that keeps going from strength to strength. v2.9 is focused on details and rolls out numerous new functions in a variety of areas like working on charts and image-based cells. GitHubÂ repo.

QI-ANXIN GROUP

tdakkota and Aleksandr Razumov

Dolev Hadar

Sablier 1.8: An API for Running Containers on Demand â€” .. and shutting them down automatically once thereâ€™s noÂ activity.

Alexis Couvreur

  • ğŸ˜ pgRoll 0.7 â€“ Zero-downtime, reversible schema migrations forÂ PostgreSQL. Now supporting PostgresÂ 17, which was released a few weeksÂ ago.

#â€‹527 â€” October 15, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

â–¶Â Â Russ Cox on Passing the Torch â€” Former Go tech lead Russ Cox went on the Go Time podcast recently to talk about the process of stepping down and handing over the reins to new leader Austin Clements (who also makes an appearance, as well as Cherry Mui who took over some of Austinâ€™s prior responsibilities). Thereâ€™s more about the changes in this post by Russ, if you missed it. (Itâ€™s an hour long podcast, but thereâ€™s a fullÂ transcript.)

Go Time Podcast podcast

'When I Told 4,091 Writers They Werenâ€™t Getting Paid..' â€” An engineer over at the annoying paywall popular writing platform shares the unfortunate tale of a subtle bug / race condition that led to a lot of writers recieving unnecessary bad news. Itâ€™s worth reading about situations like this, as they can creep up in all sorts ofÂ places.

Jacob Bennett (Medium)

Run GitHub Actions Up to 2x Faster at Half theÂ Cost â€” Blacksmith runs your GitHub Actions substantially faster by running them on modern gaming CPUs. Integrating Blacksmith is a one-line code change. 100+ companies like Ashby, Superblocks, and Slope use Blacksmith to help developers merge codeÂ faster.

Blacksmith sponsor

Gomponents 1.0: HTML View Components in Pure Go â€” We first linked to this over three years ago, and itâ€™s not only going strong, itâ€™s hit v1.0. Now a stable, dependency-free HTML component library for your Go projects (thereâ€™s also an example app to lookÂ through).

Markus WÃ¼stenberg

IN BRIEF:

  • David Mytton shares some lessons from running WebAssembly in production with Go and the Wazero runtime.

  • x = ?: I think we need a Go version of this Haskell-oriented dictionary of single letter variable names!

  • equ is a simple, Go-powered mathematical equation editor built on top of the recent released Tk 9.0 bindings for Go.

ğŸ“º How to Work with the GitHub API from Go â€“ A 22-minute screencast largely focused on gettingÂ authenticated. package main

ğŸ“„ CPU Throttling for Containerized Go Apps Explained â€“ A gotcha that â€œcan have majorÂ consequences.â€ Kanishk Singh

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Go Blueprint: Create New Go Projects with a Defined Structure â€” One of an increasing number of tools (GoForge is another) for spinning up a new Go project with a pre-defined file structure and some code generation. This one lets you spin up an app based on Chi, Gin, Fiber, or other frameworks, as well as database support, and optional tooling like HTMX and TailwindÂ CSS. GitHub repo.

Melkey

Automate Complex Workflows Across Clouds & Data Platforms â€” Kestra scales to millions of executions, automating workflows across AWS, GCP, Snowflake, and moreâ€”seamless andÂ reliable.

Kestra sponsor

Toxiproxy 2.10: A TCP Proxy to Simulate 'Chaotic' NetworkÂ Conditions â€” A long standing Shopify project designed to stress your systemâ€™s reliability and failure handling when it comes to underlying network issues. Toxiproxy can add latency, limit bandwidth, or close connections after a certain amount of data isÂ transferred.

Shopify

GoToSocial 0.17.0: A Go-Powered ActivityPub Server â€” ActivityPub is the standard behind open federated social networks such as Mastodon. This isnâ€™t Mastodon but does offer some compatibility with its API so you can use Mastodon client apps withÂ it.

Super Serious Business

Greenmask: Postgres Data Masking and Obfuscation Tool â€” A Go-powered utility for dumping a Postgres database and anonymizing the data in a deterministic way. GitHubÂ repo.

Greenmask

ğŸ¤– RAG, AI & Permissions in Go and open source? Join our upcoming webinar to learn how you can manage RAG & authorization withÂ SpiceDB.

Go builds taking a while? Install RunsOn in your AWS account and get much faster GitHub Actions runners for 10x cheaper. 1-clickÂ install.

  • ğŸ•’ Carbon 2.4 â€“ Friendly time manipulationÂ library.

  • Risor 1.7 â€“ Fast scripting language implemented in pureÂ Go.

  • OpenTelemetry-Go 1.31 â€“ OpenTelemetry Go API andÂ SDK.

  • ğŸ¤– Go OpenAI 1.32 â€“ An OpenAI API wrapperÂ library.

  • Buf 1.45 â€“ Tool for working with ProtocolÂ Buffers.

  • Fx 1.23 â€“ Dependency injection system for Go.

#â€‹529 â€” October 29, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Awesome Go: Almost 3000 Categorized Go Resources â€” A perennially useful resource that continues to get frequent updates (almost non-stop), and well worth revisiting in this quiet week for Go. You can contribute projects of your own to the listÂ too.

Awesome Go

Writing Benchmarks: Performance Testing in Go â€” A handy article that lays out all thatâ€™s possible with Goâ€™s benchmarking tests. After reviewing the toolâ€™s myriad parameters, Willem provides a full repo-backed example to show it off inÂ action.

Willem Schots

WorkOS: The Modern Identity Platform for B2BÂ SaaS â€” WorkOS is a modern identity platform for B2B SaaS, offering flexible and easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and FGA in minutes instead of months. It's trusted by hundreds of high-growth startups such as Perplexity, Vercel, andÂ Cursor.

WorkOS sponsor

â–¶Â Â ğŸ¤–Â Exploring AI-Powered Solutions with Ollama and LangChainÂ Go â€” Ollama is used to run open source large language models locally and LangChain Go makes it easy to build Go-powered apps that lean on suchÂ LLMs.

Bill Kennedy

Why Go Developers Should Try Odin â€” Odin is a lesser known but well featured programming language that the author says is part Go and part â€˜features you wished Go hadâ€™. Itâ€™s worth having on your radar even if you donâ€™t adoptÂ it.

(a)RManos

ğŸ¤ Along similar lines, John Arundel went on go podcast() to talk about why learning Rust is a good idea for Go developersÂ too.

'Jia Tanning' Go Code â€” 'Jia Tan' here refers to essentially â€˜backdooringâ€™ a codebase with code that appears to be test code but isnâ€™t, by the use of sneakily formattedÂ filenames.

Martin Tournoij

Fuzz Testing Go HTTP Services â€” You canâ€™t possibly test all of the potential inputs your app could get, so why not let your computer bombard your service and see where thingsÂ break?

Alex Pliutau

Free Course: Temporal 101 with Go â€” ğŸ“ Join this course to learn the basics of Temporal and use Temporalâ€™s Go SDK to build an app that communicates with an externalÂ service.

Temporal Technologies sponsor

ğŸ“„ Writing an HTTP Router for AWS Lambda Functions From Scratch with Go Dimitar Andreev

ğŸ“„ Lisp vs. Go â€“ If youâ€™re not tired of the language comparisonsÂ yet. Abstract Heresies

ListMonk 4.0: Self-Hosted Newsletter and Mailing List Manager â€” If you donâ€™t want to pay to use a hosted newsletter system, how about a one binary Go solution? v4.0 is a major upgrade introducing multi-user management and auth features (including OIDC), support for CC and BCC headers, syntax highlighting in email HTML, and more. GitHubÂ repo.

Kailash Nadh

go-graphviz: Go Bindings for Graphviz â€” Graphviz is a popular open source graph visualization toolkit and this library lets you use it from Go by way of a cross-platform friendly WebAssembly build. You can now encode/decode DOT notated graphs and render them to SVG or PNG without needing to install Graphviz itself on yourÂ system.

Masaaki Goshima

yq: Portable CLI YAML, JSON and XML Processor â€” jq is a popular tool for working with JSON from the command line â€“ yq takes a similar idea to even moreÂ formats. Plus it's built in Go!

Mike Farah

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Turo simplified authorization with SpiceDB. LearnÂ how.

ğŸ’› If you're a JavaScript developer or just need to keep up with the modern JavaScript landscape, check out our sister newsletter JavaScript Weekly. Last week's issue had a ton of greatÂ stuff.

  • TinyGo 0.34 â€“ The Go compiler for 'small places', like microcontrollers and WebAssembly. v0.34 adds support for go:wasmexport as a standardized way to export WebAssembly functions to theÂ host.

  • FastHTTP 1.57 â€“ Performance-oriented alternative to net/http for specific high-volumeÂ scenarios.

  • pdfcpu 0.9 â€“ Go PDFÂ processor. You can now update individual images inÂ PDFs.

  • Roaring 2.4 â€“ 'Roaring' bitmap data structureÂ implementation.

  • notify 1.0.1 â€“ Library to send notifications to various services.

  • progressbar 3.17 â€“ Basic thread-safe progressÂ bar.

  • Traefik 3.2 â€“ Popular Go-powered app proxy.

  • Bun 1.2.5 â€“ SQL-first ORM forÂ Go.

#â€‹526 â€” October 8, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Reflecting on Go Reflection â€” Truly a reflective opinion piece, and probably a divisive one too. As a programmer who chooses to use â€œthe most mundane featuresâ€ of any language, Goâ€™s reflect package wasnâ€™t on Neilâ€™s list of things to try, but he â€œfell into the reflection poolâ€ and.. heâ€™s still not aÂ fan.

Neil Macneale

I'm Glad I Did It in Go â€” Thorsten, author of Writing an Interpreter in Go, reflects on how Go was the right language for the book, eight yearsÂ on.

Thorsten Ball

Elevate Your Backend Skills â€” Whether it's Python, Go, TypeScript, or AWS, you can gain fundamental knowledge across multiple programming languages, expanding your skillset via our growing range of learning paths and expert-led videoÂ courses.

Frontend Masters sponsor

sync.Map: The Right Tool for the Right Job â€” The latest in Phuongâ€™s popular, illustrated guide to concurrency options in Go digs into sync.Map, a concurrency-safe map for reading and writing across multiple goroutines without requiring explicit locks. Itâ€™s not always the perfect choice, though, as heÂ discovers.

Phuong Le

IN BRIEF:

  • â­ Microsoft has unveiled its new go-sqlcmd CLI app for SQL Server and Azure SQL and it's written in Go! Anna Hoffman â–¶ï¸ quickly explains itÂ here.
